title: 107_s165
content: The "Family Agriculture Recovery and Market (FARM) Equity Act of 2001" is cited in Section 1. Section 132 of the Agricultural Market Transition Act is amended regarding loan rates for marketing assistance loans. The loan rates for wheat and corn under marketing assistance loans are determined based on the average prices received by producers over the past 5 crops, excluding the highest and lowest years, or set at a minimum of $3.14 per bushel for wheat and 85% of the average price for corn. The loan rates for other feed grains like grain sorghum, barley, and oats are determined based on their feeding value in relation to corn, with a minimum loan rate set by the Secretary. The marketing assistance loan rates for grain sorghum, barley, and oats are set at 85% of the average price received by producers over the past 5 years, excluding the highest and lowest years, or at specific rates of $1.89 per bushel for grain sorghum, $2.01 per bushel for barley. The loan rate for upland cotton under a marketing assistance loan is determined by the Secretary based on the average price of cotton in the United States over a 5-year period, ensuring it is not less than 85% of the average price. The loan rate for upland cotton is determined by the Secretary based on the average price of cotton in the United States over a 5-year period, ensuring it is not less than 85% of the average price, excluding the highest and lowest years or 90% of the average of the 5 lowest-priced growths of cotton. The loan rate for upland cotton in the United States spot markets is set by the Secretary and shall not be less than $0.5826 per pound. For extra long staple cotton, the loan rate is either 85% of the average price over 3 years, excluding the highest and lowest years, or $0.8768 per pound. The loan rates for rice and soybeans under marketing assistance loans are determined based on the average prices received by producers, with minimum rates set at $7.81 per hundredweight for rice and not less than 85% of the average price for soybeans. The loan rates for sunflower seed, canola, rapeseed, safflower, mustard seed, and flaxseed are determined based on the average prices received by producers, with minimum rates set at 85% of the average price for the preceding 5 marketing years. The loan rates for various oilseeds are determined based on the average prices received by producers over the past 5 marketing years, excluding the highest and lowest years. The rates are set at $0.093 per pound for oil sunflower seed, $0.1176 per pound for nonoil sunflower seed, $0.0945 per pound for canola, $0.1001 per pound for rapeseed, $0.1259 per pound for safflower, $0.1176 per pound for mustard seed, and $0.093 per pound for flaxseed. The loan rates for other oilseeds are determined by the Secretary to be fair and reasonable in relation to soybeans, with a minimum rate set on a per-pound basis for the same crop. SEC. 3. Nonrecourse marketing assistance loans and loan deficiency payments for dry peas, lentils, chickpeas, and rye. Amendments are made to the Agricultural Market Transition Act regarding loan commodities, including dry peas, lentils, chickpeas, and rye. Loan rates for these commodities are specified in the amendments. The Agricultural Market Transition Act specifies loan rates for dry peas, lentils, chickpeas, and rye, with prices based on producers' average earnings over previous years. The Agricultural Market Transition Act specifies loan rates for dry peas, lentils, chickpeas, and rye, with prices based on producers' average earnings over previous years. The Act also amends payment limitations to include these commodities in addition to contract commodities and oilseeds. The Act and its amendments apply to the 2001 and 2002 crops of loan commodities as defined in the Agricultural Market Transition Act.
